titleStmt.title: London, Sotheby’s Auction House, Arts Of The Islamic World, 20 April 2016, Lot 10

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

msIdentifier.idno: Arts Of The Islamic World, 20 April 2016, Lot 10

summary.p: Single leaf Qur'an manuscript on parchment; London, Ms. Sotheby's, 20. April 2016, Lot 10; 18 lines to the page; Ex-private collection, France, sold to Sotheby's on 20. April, 2016; Script style: early kūfī type B.I.
Another folio from the same manuscript was sold at Millon, Paris on 15-16. June 2022, lot. 128. The C-14 dating of the fragment from Paris resulted in 649-778 AD with 95% confidence.
Further information can also be found on Sotheby's website.

The script of the fragment is close to the kūfī style B.I with the influence of ḥiǧāzī and kūfī C.Ia (Déroche 1992). The letter ʾalif is slanting to the right slightly, as in ḥiǧāzī and kūfī B.Ia scripts. The letters ǧīm/ḥāʾ/ḫāʾ in the initial position resembles the letter seen in the C.Ia group. Within a word, the letter rests on the base line as those in C.Ia. In one case on the fol. 1r. of the sister fragment from Millon, Paris the letter in the medial position has a form of an oblique bar that crosses the base line, like in the B.I group. The final form of the letter is also identical to the C.Ia group, where the tail of the letter is horizontal. When initial, the letter ʿayn is close to those of ḥiǧāzī IV with the upper hook being angular rather than round. In the medial form the letter is identical to those of B.II group, the two antennas are difficult to distinguish, but the right one is vertical. In the final position the letter shows two different shapes: when isolated, the tail lies horizontally on the base line . When connected to the previous letter, the form resembles those of B.Ia. The qāf in final position is identical to B.II. On the fol. 1r. of the sister fragment from Millon, Paris the isolated qāf shows resemblance to the B.I group. The letter hāʾ in the initial or medial position rests on the base line, the bar is vertical, resembling the form seen in ḥiǧāzī IV manuscripts. As for lām-ʾalif, the two arms of the ligature curve away from each other, other than in B.I where they are leaning towards each other.
The vocalisation is made by red dots. The diacritical marking happens occasionally and is made by oblique dashes.
Typical letter shapes are presented in the palaeographic table, accessible as image no. 2 under fol. 1r. (Salome Beridze)
